awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Princeton Neuroscience Institute Summer Internship Program
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Princeton University, located in Princeton, NJ, will support the training of 10 students for 9 weeks during the summers of 2018- 2020. All students will be mentored by faculty associated with the Princeton Neuroscience Institute (PNI) and will be offered a GRE preparatory course; computer programming classes; and other activities designed to help summer students prepare for graduate school. Summer researchers are required to participate in laboratory and safety training seminars and a workshop on the responsible conduct of research. PNI's summer research program is for undergraduates who are seriously considering graduate studies in neuroscience. PNI seeks to support students whose participation will add to the diversity of researchers in the sciences, and are from institutions that do not have large neuroscience research programs. Applicants are required to submit an online application, an unofficial transcript and two letters of recommendation.  Completed applications are evaluated by program staff and faculty. Program participants are asked to join PNI's LinkedIn group and create an ORCID account to assist PNI in monitoring their academic and professional progress.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Given the importance of a research experience in the graduate admissions process, this program will provide students with opportunities that they might not otherwise be able to obtain. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://pni.princeton.edu/summer-programs/pni-summer-internship-program/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Jonathan Cohen at jdc@princeton.edu) or the Program Director (Dr. Ed Clayton at ec12@princeton.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The PNI Summer Internship Program has been a great success for the Institute and the University. We have offered a 9 week research experience to 10+ students per year (minus one COVID year) since 2019. Since that first year of funding, we have steadily added and streamlined programming to reflect the needs of our students. The program has always offered, in addition to the research experience, faculty talks, introductory coding classes in Python and Matlab, and professional development activities. We also have offered students an opportunity to present their research at an end of summer poster session. We also offered for several years a GRE preparatory course, which ended in summer 2022 as most neuroscience graduate schools have pivoted away from requiring GRE scores as part of the application process. We have also enhanced the program in a number of ways. We have added an advanced Python and programming in R courses. Beginning in 2022, we also began hosting summer intern reunions where we brought back former interns currently in graduate programs or research assistant positions to counsel our current interns on lessons learned during the internship program, grad program application process, and graduate school itself. We have started a weekly professional development workshop where we discuss the intracies of grad school, applying to grad school, and surviving/thriving in a graduate program. In addition, Princeton is a member of the Leadership Alliance so we annually attend their National Symposium where our summer students give oral presentations about their summer work. In 2022 we also had many of our students present at the Faculty for Undergraduate Neuroscience poster session at the Society for Neuroscience annual meeting. Our programming is always evolving as we bring in new students with new ideas and needs.

 

Of 36 students supported during this period, 17 are currently in PhD programs, 2 are in MD/PhD programs, 1 is in a PsyD program, and 4 are in research assistant positions with an intention to apply for graduate programs in the near future (67%). Of the other students who chose not to seek a graduate degree, they have entered into positions in University administration and the biotech industry.

 


Last Modified: 07/06/2023
Modified by: Jonathan D Cohen
